sp.p: By Heaven I am in earnest: try. In earnest? yes.—Come let me lead you to my chamber,—and give you the first clear proof of my intire passion.— [Offers to pull her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know you can but jeast.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I'l convince you above.—Dear, Madam, come.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And wou'd you wrong your Uncle?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why do you name him? he's not so just to you, you may Cuckold him with less sin, than lye with him; for then you are in danger, for he's a spark abroad, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How can you tell?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Oh, I have heard it every where.—But what needs all this Ceremony?—come let's up.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Unhand me. If you provoke me, I'l undo you.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: She's angry,—what a Pox, have I mistaken her? [Aside.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is this the best construction you can make of all my kindness to you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pox on't, I am not mistaken in her neither, but [Aside. apply'd my self to her, too soon after her young Monsieur had left her.—E'gad I'l tell her so too.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I see a penitence in your face, George, for what you've done; and if 'tis true, I can easily forgive you;—but here comes my woman.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: The Devil take her.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Madam.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look that you never tempt me so again. [Aside to him.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Then I must dye, unless you'l yield without it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look handsomely, and do not betray your self, and for once you are safe.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: So, she'l come about again. [Aside.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, go Cozin, and do that Affair for me I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I go, Madam, I have my instructions all?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, George, if you can remember.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Oh, witty Devil, how she has turn'd the discourse! by which I find she puts no faith in old Maulkeena there: I love her invention. [Ex. Careless.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: A Citizen waits to speak with you, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Mr. Saleware, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sure his Aly has impudently told him what I have done.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: There's a Gentlewoman too, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bring 'em in. [Ex. Closet.
sp.stage: Re-enters with Tom Saleware and Phebe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly desire a word or two with your Ladyship, concerning my Cozen Phebe here: She's abus'd by a Gentleman that lies here, as I understand; Mr. Careless, Madam, who has damag'd her much.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Read this, Madam, 'twill inform you of the truth of what I say,—hold up your head, Phebe, we'll not be dasht in a good Cause.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Madam,

My Uncle's favour has incourag'd me to make my humble adresses to you in the way of holy Marriage, I shall not be altogether unworthy the Honour of being your Husband, since I may justly enough hope my Estate may be sutable to your desires: 'Tis long that I have had a passion for you, and impatient till I find whether 'twill be receiv'd well by you. If you vouchsafe to do so, I shall not only declare my self a good and grateful Husband, but live the happyest of all men,
Ever yours, G. Careless.
This is so far from injury, that me thinks 'tis very kind.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O but Madam, he is gone from his word, and denies this his Act and deed, like a disloyal man; and having born her in hand thus long, wou'd now cast her off: Sent his man to ravish the Letter from her, but never the sooner for a hasty word. Cozin, we'll not be dasht nor basht, I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: To the fair hands of Mrs. Phebe Gimcrack.— Is that your name?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I am the wretched thing that owns it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will endeavour to serve you, Mr. Saleware,—if I knew how.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam, you are discreet, and if your Ladyship takes this matter in hand, I doubt not but to see my Cozin happy, and a good end of the business; but if it cannot be, I shall find Friends, nor shall her Cause be starv'd for want of monies, as they say: For we will not be dasht, nor basht; Sapientia mea mihi, is my word, and so dear Madam, I have discharg'd my mind.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Saleware, I'll take care of your Kinswoman, and do my best for her.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Madam. Phebe, do you mind me? Bear your self to this Noble Lady handsomly, and high, as becomes the Family you came off; She may chance do you more good than all my high talking: I pray carry it high;— or,—Sapientia mea mihi, Stultitia tua tibi; that's my Motto.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: O doubt not me, Sir; nor my Carriage.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Closett, take this young Woman up to your Chamber, and treat her well; I will do something for her: doubt not, Mr. Saleware. [Ex. Closett, and !Phebe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: How I shall be bound to your Ladyship. Ex. Lady. —So, now will I home, and see if my Wife be come yet, or not, she has been out all day, and night too; but this I must bear, as we are Friends: for Sapientia, is my Motto.— [Ex. Tom.

div.head: SCENE,
A Shop.
div.stage: Discovers Alitia in it fine, with Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
I see you design to kill me, you wou'd not else let me be a witness to those Joys, which my Lord only reaps, and
must look on and languish for, to conduct you to him; after that undress you, and lay you,—O, I dare not name where, but, wou'd I might never live to see him embrace you more.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not soften me so, you dissembling thing you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By all that's good, I am not, I speak truth.—O how you lay this morning wrapt in his dear embraces.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Well, and did not you come from being wrapt in dear imbraces too, those of my Lady Thrivewell?—once more, let me hear the pleasing story,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O if you lov'd me, as you say, you cou'd not take a pleasure in hearing what Joys I took with another?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Joys which you give, I can. Come let me hear how kind she was, and how well she lik'd you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So well she lik'd me, that she swore and I believ'd her, she never lik'd her Husband half so well.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Some other man perhaps she did.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She vow'd, and I again believ'd; she never knew a man besides her Husband.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: And your self,—but then she was kind?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very kind.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: And cou'd you,—when you pretended to me, cou'd you? Ah you're a cozening thing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Inspir'd with thoughts of you; I was grateful to her Ladyship, and she in requital to your kindness, for sending me, has sent you a hundred Guinies.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I, was she so obliging? Where be they?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: At my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: O the Subtilty of these men! for fear I shou'd not keep my assignation, yon think to oblige me that way, to come to you; but you may believe, my dear Bellamy, I am all yours, and will be so when e're you name the time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
On my Conscience, my wife's not come home yet: Well, thus it must be, in spight of chance, and high heel Shoes which will go a wry sometimes. How a Lady there,—and my Wife not with her?—hah,—my Wife? Stay, are my Eyes mine own?—'tis she—my friend Wife, in that t'other end o'th'
Town habit she has so long wisht for: but, Mr. Bellamy, and she are whispering, I must not yet advance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This night let it be.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: You have had enough of your Lady, sure for one day?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Doubt me not, dearest, Madam?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So, Madam, is't come to that? wou'd they had done, that I might approach without interruption.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: And with all faith and secresie, I am undone else: for you know my vows to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You undo me with these suspitions.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: See my Husband.—Pray, Sir, present my service, and humble thanks, to my Lord, and my Husbands too.—

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, I beseech you, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will obey you, Madam.— [Ex. Bell.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: —Still, I say, this is an Assenego, he will never stand a Complement with me: But, Sapientia mea mihi;—but, what new Graces has his Lordship done us, that you have made me send him thanks for? For you say, you bought these rich Cloths your self.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, I am sensible, and you may leave your silly impertinent inquisitions.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I stand corrected, Friend.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: And stand still corrected, or I shall break the Peace with you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Before I marry'd you, did not my Lord make you Indent with me, to ask me no Questions, to deny me nothing I had a mind too, either for wearing, or eating, or going abroad where and with whom I pleas'd; and did you not agree to all this?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I did, and will still hold to my Indentures with my Noble Lord: whose favor I wou'd not loose, for Forty Indentures.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: O wou'd you not so.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And what the dickins care I for my spightful Neighbours, who because they cannot maintain their Wives so fine as thou art, asperse thee,—and cry there's Tom. Salewares fine Wife: but Sapientia mea mihi, is my Motto; Let the Assenegoes tattle their hearts out, for I am resolv'd to show my self a dutiful Husband, in spight of Fortune and foul weather.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: To prevent their talking, I'll remove out of their sight, and leave your pittiful Shop keeping.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Nay, I'll do't. I have been about it: have all under one done other Business too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I cou'd tell her under who, if I durst too. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What's that you mumble there, to your self?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I was only Divining what that business shou'd be, which you did all under one; Ile warrant, you have taken fine Lodgings in the Mall, as you intended.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No, but I have taken a house there, by my Lords directions.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: How, how, what must I then break up Shop?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No indeed, look to your Shop, and keep your City house too, for your self to lie in.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Must I not then lie in the same house?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No, Friend, not unless you mean to break with me for ever.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well,—I will not disoblige thee, nor my Noble Lord, for any Consideration, for you know my Motto; Sapientia mea mihi; Stultitia tua tibi.—And so let's in to Dinner. [Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: Act Fourth. Scene First.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Crostill, Lord Loveless and Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: MAdam, I'm but a bashful Lover, unskill'd to court a Widow, to swear I love you,—must and will have you;—And want the moving confidence to stir your blood by putting you to't, before the Priest declare it lawful; —But, I have Love and tenderness, which you will find in all the Actions of my life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This modest Courtship will do no good on the Widow, he has mistook her humor. Blest mistake! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p:
My Lord, I am not worthy your regard, my Birth,
and Education, are not sutable to your great Fame. Fortune, 'tis true, was kind and gave me wealth, which sets me up a Mark for every Man, that aims at riches: Whilst all my little Beauties lie dead upon my hands, none court for that in a Wife; 'Tis enough, his Mistris shall be fair.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Madam, you seem to upbraid me with a sin, I vow, I never knew,—I am so Innocent.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: That 'twere pitty Marriage shou'd de bauc h yor Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: It cannot, Madam, I'll be so true to you,—so faithful, and so just—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Impossible! I wou'd not have you so degenerate from the true gallantry of your Sex, and Age, to be a constant Husband. O how vile a sound it has! a young Lord, and constant to his Wife! Not for the World, wou'd I be that Woman, that shou'd be guilty of making you so strange a Monster.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Madam, by my Honour, I never lov'd till now, and you may rally as you please; but, I again protest 'tis not your wealth, but Virtue I admire: and you I must possess, or be for ever wretched.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: —Stay,—let us retire again, here is the Lord Loveless.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Let there be the Devil, I'll not retire an Inch,— —Save you, Widow.— [Goes up to her: putting the Lord by roughly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: What rudeness is this?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Widow, I am in hast, and have not leasure for long whining Courtship.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Mr. Saveall, what Fellow's this, you have brought to affront me?

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: Your Pardon, good my Lord, we knew not of your Lordships being here; 'tis Mr. Careless, Nephew to Sir Oliver Thrivewell,—of whom I have procur'd the Five hundred pound, your Lordship desir'd by Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: For that I thank you; but for him, I must have an account of his rudeness.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: Pray have respect to the presence of the Widow, my good Lord.—

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: I shall do as becomes me, Sir. [Talks to Save.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Then it seems, you do not deny the Letter, to be your own hand?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: No, faith, Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: Have you the impudence to confess it?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Yes, and will not ask your Pardon for't; why what the Devil was there, that was not kind? I offer'd, if you Marry'd, to do your Drudgery, 'Egad I think you're beholden to me.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Madam, I made my first Addresses to you, and desire the favour of being first heard.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sir, she shall hear me first, whoere came first I care not, she has heard you first already; or you have lost time.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Sir, I have been heard, and I will be heard again, and what's all this to you?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But you shall not, Sir; let me see you dare speak a Syllable to this Widow; or but tell her you love her with your Eyes, and it shall be your last; by Heaven it shall.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Unhand me, Saveall.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: How dare you, Sir, use this insolence in my house? On what incouragement, or by what Authority is it?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Good pert thing, hold thy prating, for let me tell thee, I neither love thee, my self, as you perhaps vainly imagin, nor will I suffer any other to do so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: I beseech your Lordship, to Pardon him, he's certainly mad.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: The fitter for you, Widow.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Madam, the respect I bear you ties my hands, or you shou'd see I wou'd not be affronted.—Mr. Careless, you know me I suppose, and pray expect me to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I shall, Sir, I shall. You have your answer, Sir, and may be gone.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Death, shall my fears of angring her, make me endure all this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Sir, what's your business here? what have you to say to me? If any thing, say it quickly, and leave me free.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
Softly, good Widow, you are so impatient, till you hear me say, I love you,—well, know then I do love you
most abominably, and am resolv'd to Marry you, and then to use you as I list.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how old are you?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O parlous Wit! what, I warrant you expect to be Courted in fine Language;—Ah, cruel Woman, how can you treat a Gentleman that loves you dearer than his Eyes, so rigorously? One that cannot,—nay, will not, (whilst there are ways to dye,) live out of your favor. [In a whining Tone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: Who is't, you speak of, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I am the wretched Man.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: All this, and more, Sir, my heart directs to an unknown youth, who loves not me. [In a whining Tone too.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Death, but you shall not, Ile have you love none but me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: I cannot chuse, you're such a civil Person, and write such passionate stuff in your Letter.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O does that Letter trouble you? In good time, Ile write more, and worse to you hereafter, and in earnest too.—Did I not tell you the mistake, unreasonable Creature?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to say to you; and beg your Pardon, if I tell you, I desire you no more to visit me.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why, then fare you well. Ile have as good a Widow, on every Ale-house Chimney. [Sings. O she's a dainty Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: O how his humour pleases me, yet now Ile be reveng'd on't.—Sir, your Servant, will your Lordship please to walk in? This rude Fellow has disorder'd you?

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Madam, you honour your servant, and fully make amens, for all I've suffer'd, in the Allowance of this favor.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But, Sir, I am not pleas'd she shou'd allow it you. [He pushes him away.

sp.speaker: Ld Lo.
sp.p: Death, Sir, But she shall.— [Offers to draw, the rest part 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cro.
sp.p: Shall you control me, in my own house? —Pray learn to know your self.—Mr. Saveall, pray carry him away; or Ile have it done more indescently. [Ex. Lord and Widow.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
I will endure it for once; because I know 'twas done only in revenge to me.—But who's here? My fine young
dandy-prat,—and at the Widows too!—Sir, I have seen you but twice, and 'twas at places where I cannot allow of your coming, first at my Aunts, and now, here at my Widows. [Sees Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Widow, good Sir? I thought she had been the Widow of one deceas'd?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty witty child; but, Sirrah, let me find you here no more, nor at my Aunts, I charge you: if I do, I shall have you whip't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hear your Charge, Sir; but you must leave it to my discretion, whether I will obey you, or not.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Well, Sir, remember I have given you fair warning.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: Sir, will it please you to walk homeward?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You must excuse me, Sir, at present.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: It will not be convenient, Sir, to visit the Widow again to day.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O fear it not, Sir, I do not like her so well now.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: Do your pleasure, Sir,—Farewell. [Ex.Save.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: This damn'd Widow sticks in my Stomach, I am resolv'd she shall not have me now, unless she court me to't, to which end, I will go drink her out of my head, for to my heart she is not yet arriv'd; and then Ile home, and do that which only my Aunt and I must be acquainted with: this is her Night of grace, she has promis'd me to be kind; if she keep touch with me,—O how I shall love.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, they are gone.—And now must I prepare to meet Mrs. Saleware, I have a mind to try her honesty, which I believe is as little, as her faith to my Lord: I have appointed her to meet me at a certain convenient house, where I have got a Bed ready; but how to supply her with a bedfellow suitable to her humour, I cannot tell: I have therefore writ this, in an unknown name, to her Husband, who shall come and prevent the Plot, and save my credit;—but if he fail?— wou'd that were my greatest grief; but here I leave the man my soul adores, courting another, may she be deaf to all his Love, as I was to my reason, when it pleaded against his false addresses.—

div.head: SCENE,
The Lady Thrivewell's Chamber.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: In troth, I pity you, but you were to blame too, Phebe, I must needs say, to yield.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: 'Twas the effects of Love, Madam, and his solicitations.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, well, I'l see what I can do for you, tho' it be but for the pleasure of revenge for attempting me:—Closet, you know my mind,—and how to order our design?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Doubt me not, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope he will get himself fudled to night, to further it.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Then he may forget your Ladyships promise.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No, no, then he'l be the more earnest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You know his humor best that way, it seems,—but away, here comes Sir Oliver.— [Ex. Clos. and Phe.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Make love to my wife? a fine young Rogue!— Well, Watt, for this discovery, I'l reward thee bountifully. —Sweet-heart, I have a sute to you.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Pray what is't? you may command me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: 'Tis for my absence from thee, to accompany a friend to Dover, who is going for Holland.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope this is no excuse to go again to your Citizen's wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Think no more of that, Sweet-heart, but expect me to morrow at dinner; if I be not here before, and catch you napping, my free Lady. [Aside.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: His absence falls out luckily, [Ex. Sir Oliv. and Watt. lest there shou'd happen any noise in the house by his unruly Nephew, in case he shou'd discover the cheat I put upon him, his own wench instead of my self. I thought I had sufficiently chid him for his rash attempting me: and he to pursue it, and urge me to a promise!—which I made to be rid of him, is what I must be reveng'd on him for.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Your Nephew is come, Madam, and very much uppish (as they say) but not so far gon as to forget your Ladyships Promise, and he is gone to bed, in expectation of your coming.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And have you drest his Mistris up, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Oh, most famously, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But have you charg'd her to steal from him, before it is light?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Yes, I have, Madam. [Ex. La. Closet.

div.stage: Enter Bellamy, and Tom Saleware, as in a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why Lord, Mr. Bellamy, you are the strangest man in the World, to think I am jealous, because I ask for my Aly. I am an Asenego, if I be.—.But yet I know she's here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why look you now, is not this jealousie, not to believe me?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, you equivocate, Mr.Bellamy, I protest you do; she is not indeed here at the door, but I'l warrant you she's above, but what's that to me?—Alas, Sir, it cannot make me jealous.— I hope I shall see her safe at home, some time or other, at her own leisure.—But it is a hard case tho.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now are you relapsing into your jealousie again?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What an Asenego's this? there's no man in the City more confident of his wife, than I am of my Aly: nor will I be dasht or basht at any scandalous reports that go of her, therefore tell me, whether she's here or no, for I don't come to disturb her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There, you are jealous again.—But to end all disputes, Sir, your wife is here, and I believe going to bed by this time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why what a notable merry Scab are you, Mr. Bellamy? —Away, away, I faith you're a Wag now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, you will not believe me now?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Believe you? why no, by my troth, not I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What made you fancy she was here?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
I fancy, Sir, I have as few fancies as any man breathing, —but I receiv'd a Note from one Mr. Spywell, hinting that my Aly was to lye with a certain Friend here all night.—A very pleasant bus'ness; as if I believ'd it:—not I, Sir, I protest, for
she has no friend but my Lord, and as if he wou'd bring her to such a place as this, he having such Lodgings of his own, and she a House—is a ridiculous bus'ness.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why did you come then?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: To see the meaning of this Spywell's Letter, who bid me come and inquire for you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, and here I am.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well, and what of that? he's an Asenego that inquires further: and so farewell to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, I was that Spywell that writ to you, for I knowing you had not lain with your wife this three months, out of pure kindness, laid this Plot, that you might come and lye with her here.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, and is she here indeed?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come along with me, and be convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: This is a Plot laid by my wife to oblige me: I am sure 'tis so. Ah little Rogue, how I will pay thy kindness! [Ex. after Bellamy.

div.head: SCENE,
A Bed chamber
div.stage: Ali. sitting in her Night-gown at a Table, undressing her. To her Bell. and Tom at the door.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you say I sent for you, you'l spoil all, but you must say you came by inspiration, or that you were inform'd in a dream, or a vision, or so forth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I warrant you, Mr. Bellamy, for Acting my part well. My wife has laid this Plot to give me a sure proof of her honesty.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Credulous fool!—well stand you behind this door, and I'l go in and speak to her.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, I'l warrant you, I'l stand close.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Bellamy, are you come? you are a fine man, to make me languish thus long without you, are you not?—Come, hast to undress you, and let us to bed.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So, very good, ha, ha, ha.— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What does your Passion that was to day so high, decay already?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That's pleasant again, as if I were such a fool, to think such an Asenego as he had ever had a Passion for her,—ha, ha, ha.— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Did you only court me to a consent to despise me for it afterwards?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: As if she had ever consented to lye with my Lord's man; a pretty bus'ness, that. [Aside still.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Or you perhaps, malitious as you are, courted me only to try me, and then betray me.—Will you not answer me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I am so surpris'd with an accident that you little dream of, that I am not able to utter a word.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Was there ever such witty waggish Rogues seen as these two? what a pretty Plot have they laid to make me jealous?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Speak again, what is it has happen'd?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Death, I cou'd find in my heart to kill the cuckoldly Idiot, the horn'd beast, for preventing my dear expectations thus.—

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: As I am a Christian, this is very pretty sport, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What's the matter? what Cuckold, my husband?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I know not by what damn'd Witchcraft, but he knows we are here; the Devil assisted him sure to find us.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Oh, I am ruin'd then: he'l tell all to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word.—I shou'd ruin my self then too: no, no, sapientia mea mihi, is my Motto; be not dasht or basht for that, good Friend. [Tom comes out to her.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Hath, my husband's here indeed.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: As sure as you are there, sweet Ali. What, you thought to make me jealous now? but I thank my reason, I have more grace than so: no, I know what's what, as my Friend Hudibras has it. Make me jealous! honest Tom?—no, Mr. Bellamy, I am beholden to you.—But how I came hither, you shall never know, nor, do you hear me talk of any Letter or Porter that came to give me intelligence, no, nor name, Mr. Spywell, not I, sapientia, is my Motto.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Death! the fool will out with all. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What means all this?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I mean? I know what you mean; come, come, never blush for the matter, you might have told me you had a mind to.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: To what, Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I, I, never put on this fain'd anger, the Plot is discover'd, and I am not jealous.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What Plot?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That you had a mind to do me the honour of letting me lye with you to night, and now 'tis out.—Mr. Bellamy, I hope we shall have your company, tho not in the same bed, and E'faith, we'l have a Sack-Posset before we go to bed, sweet Ali.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What a defeat is here!—
Mr. Bellamy, hark ye.—Thomas, be at a distance.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Face about, Tom. [Turns.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: You have betray'd me every way: I see it plain, and will be reveng'd on you, if I live.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who, I by all.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No swearing, you are a young Hypocrite: where's the hundred Guineys you had for me,—you said?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And have;—but shall I give them you before your husband?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Come, come, I see I am abus'd and fool'd; who was it sent for him, hath?—not you, I'l warrant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not I, I vow by your fair dear self, and am so mad, that he has defeated me, that if you'l give me leave, I'l kill him, to enjoy thee.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No, hold; if this be true, I'm reconcil'd again, and pray let's meet again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: May all that's man about me forsake me, if I lose any opportunity: and so I'l take my leave.— [Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, E'faith we'l have a Sack-Posset, as I said, before we go to bed.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Well, tho I seem to believe him, I am resolv'd he has done me this injury.
sp.l: And when a willing woman is so crost,
All thoughts, but of revenge, are lost.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Tell me, Ali. indeed, how you came hither.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: You will not be angry then?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I am an Asenego, if I be.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: It was indeed to make thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Now hang me, if I did not imagin so: nay, nay, I can prophesie right sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: And how do you think you were brought hither?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, I can prophesie that too: Mr. Spywell's Letter— but I'l say no more.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let's see the Letter.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Hah,—where is't?—hum,—have I lost it?—and sacks so I have.—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Well, well, 'twas I that sent it, Simpleton.—

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why didst thou indeed, and indeed?—Well, let's to bed, for I am now so in love with thy pretty Project, that I fancy strange things: Come, let's to bed, we'l get a Sibyl or a small Prophet this night. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE,
Sir Oliver's House.
div.stage: Enter Phebe, passing over the Stage in a Night-Gown, Careless after her, groping as in the dark, in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Oh stay, my dear Aunt, stay, 'tis not near day yet, we have many minutes of joy to come ere that approach.—She's gone,—I heard her Chamber door open,—wou'd I cou'd find it,—my Uncle's not at home, and I'l go to her there.—Who's this? one with lights?

div.stage: Enter Lady with a light, and in a Night Gown.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you, that you make such a noise at this hour.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Wou'd it not make a man distracted to be so soon left by so sweet, so dear a Creature?—Come let's retire again.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sure you are mad to desire it, 'twill ruin us both.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I'l warrant you: my charming obliging Aunt!—

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Oh Madam, don't you hear some body knock at the door? on my conscience 'tis Sir Oliver, by the authority of clamour he makes there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: E'gad and so do I, I hope 'tis that Rogue Watt, having forgot I have turn'd him away, and is drunk. Come,—let's retire again, can we be sensible of any thing but joy?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Hark ye, Closet,—go.— [Whispers.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: It shall be so. [Ex. Closet.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That was kind, and well thought on, to give her instructions what to do.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You cannot guess at what I said.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why, to tell my Uncle, that—you are not well,—and desire him to lye by himself to night, or—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou art so lewd a fellow, thou canst not think one sober thought of me, which makes me now repent the favors I have done thee: be gone, and see my face no more.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: How unreasonable is a woman when her own turn's serv'd!—Hark ye, dear Aunt.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Approach me not; if thou dost, I'l raise the house.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Unmerciful creature! do not provoke my love, which is so high, 'tis arriv'd almost to rage, do not; you know not what 'twill make me do, for now you are in my power, have a care,— I say, have a care.—

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver at the door, with Watt and Saveall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Dare you do so base a thing, as to proclaim my shameful kindness? perjur'd man!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why do you provoke me then, do you think to kindle a fire in my heart, and let it burn out alone? No, I am resolv'd it shall be laid.—Come, come, by all that's good, dear Aunt, I love you; and love you ten times more since you were kind, then before, and I think the Devil's in you if you desire a man shou'd do more.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Alas, that ever you were kind.—How prettily this penitence becomes you. Come, now a tear or two, and then—thou wilt be fit to be undone again.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Oh Monster, Villain, Rascal, what dost thou merit for this baseness, but death immediately from my hand?—And thou false woman, that hast thus betray'd me.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What Devil sent him hither?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Can I hear more to convince me thou art false, or I unhappy,—then what I've heard already?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I was not so unreasonable when Mrs. Saleware and you were kind.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And did you, perfidious woman, pardon me that, to be reveng'd on me this way.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Mistake me not, nor wrong me: I have only show'd you what some wou'd have done.—Sir, 'twas my design, to let you see this extravagance of your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O witty, dear Devil, how I love thee for thy rare quality —of dissembling.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, she's the falsest woman.— [To Saveall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Mr. Saveall, you have ever been most obliging, pray perswade Sir Oliver to retire into my Chamber, and hear with patience what I have to say to him, he shall find there the cause of this mistake.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: I'l do my best to serve you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And dost thou think ever to reconcile me?—

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: 'Twill not be the part of a judicious man to condemn before the cause be heard, good Sir Oliver, as I take it, let me intreat that justice from you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I will hear you, tho no false tale thou canst devise, shall perswade me against my senses. But, Sirrah, for your part—get you out of my doors, I'l see thee starve and beg, for an ungrateful reprobate, as thou art.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Indeed you must not put him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: How! dare you take his part?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, I dare and will justifie it, nor shall you give him a word or look, that declares anger, you shall not, Sir, 'till you have heard me, and then take your course.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Kind soul! I cou'd kiss her all over for this. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: You're very confident, but I'l forbear, till I've heard you, tho thou canst say nothing to make me think thou'rt innocent.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go,—go to bed again, George, and sleep, without fear of any thing, all shall be well again. [Ex. Sir Oliv. and all but Care.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sweet dear charming gilt, how I love thee! now will she manage my Uncle so, that 'tis ten to one but I shall be rewarded for my nights work to morrow: but Lord, how she thought to terrifie me, with chiding me, and repenting her kindness to me. Now—go to bed, George, ha, ha, ha.—
sp.l: Well go thy ways; I know thy Plots will hit:
There's nothing like a womans sudden wit.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: Act Fifth. Scene, The Lord's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: TO speak with me?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Bring em in. [Ex. Page, returns with Tom. Saleware and Alice.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Pray, Thomas, attend at a distance.

sp.speaker: Tom.
Lor.
sp.p: How now, in tears, why is that lovely face where all my souls delight dwells, thus strangly drest in sorrow?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Alas, my dear Lord.—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Who is t dares injure thee? I know thy Husband is better manner'd, than to offend thee; and any other cannot escape with life.—Come name the cause.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: There is a man has Injur'd me; but one below you, my dear Lord, to take notice of, your servant Bellamy may do't. Do you believe him honest, my dear Lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Most perfectly so, if I have any judgment.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I know, my dear Lord, you ever esteem'd him so: but, —if your Lordship had a Jewel, or any other thing, you valu'd and wou'd reserve for your own wearing, wou'd you let him enjoy it too?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I know not any thing I shou'd refuse him the use of: except, thy dear self, where I can brook no Rivals.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Yet he, my Lord, has wickedly attempted me, and in that has wrong'd your Honour, and your trust.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You surp • ize me!

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: My Lord, 'is truth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It cannot be. I know he durst not do't.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Must I not then find credit?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Give me some circumstances, but to prove it.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Tho if I had said it only, 'twere sufficient: yet you shall have circumstances. Thomas,—come hither Thomas. Pray tell his Lordship, what you heard and saw, last night between Mr. Bellamy, and I.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why may't please your Lordship, my Ali. was abroad all the afternoon yesterday, as she often is, may't please your Lordship, and may as often be again, an't please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: 'Tis well,—forward.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well, out she was, an't please your Lordship, it grew late, and no Ali. came, it grew later and no Ali. came yet, so that Ie'en concluded she wou'd stay all night, an't please your Lordship, as she has done many a night, an't please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Prethee proceed.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I shall, an't please your Lordship. It being late, an't like your Lordship, as I said before, an't please your Lordship, I had word brought me, an't please your Lordship, that my Ali. was to lye with a Friend, an't please your Lordship, at a certain house in Drury Lane, an't please your Lordship; well, I went, and because I hate to be tedious, or hold your Lordship in a long tale, I will only say, an't please your Lordship, I went thither, as I said, and found my Ali. just undrest for Bed, Mr. Bellamy, ready to go into Bed to her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It cannot be!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Be? why Ile justifie it, an't please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Then your Wife's guilty too; how came she thither?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I hope you will not think so ill of me, my dear Lord, alas, I was betray'd, the cunning Villain told me your Lordship was to be there, and desir'd my company; when I came and found you not, he bid me undress me, and get me to bed, and you, my dear Lord, wou'd come to me. At last I finding 'twas but a Cheat, and not knowing how to get away, writ a Note to my Husband, to come and relieve me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Is't possible a man that weeps, and blushes, shou'd be such an one?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I vow to Gad, an't please your Lordship, I fancy'd all the while they had but play'd the wag, to make me jealous; and Ali. (ah, the little cunning Gipsie) knowing I was peeping at the door. Cry'd come to bed, Mr. Bellamy, make hast and undress you, Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Peace, Fool,—he'll spoil all.— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Mum.—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I do not like this. Where's the Letter?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Here, an't please your Lordship.— [Gives him the Letter.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: The Devil take you for giving him the Letter. You said you had lost it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I thought so Friend; but I found it since.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Thou'dst better have swallow'd it full of Opium.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I wou'd I had so too, for me, rather than have offended thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Mr. Saleware, If you wou'd not be a worse Cuckold than you are, come away to the Joyners in Drury Lane, it being a convenient Bawdy-house, and you will find your Wife there, ready to add to your Horns.
Yours, Spywell.
—What means this? 'tis Bellamy's own hand.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: How shall I come off now?—Why does not your Lordship see how excellent I am at counterfeiting hands? I fain'd Mr. Bellamy's Character, a purpose: It's not well.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This Woman's, false, I see't.—Who waits?
—Where's Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: He has not been at home to night, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I hope your Lordship will believe me now; but I was told he pay'd his visit to my Lady Thrivewell, this morning.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He is to receive money there for me, pray Heaven he be true, I scarce dare trust him. Tho I cannot believe what this false Woman says. Get my Coach ready, Ile go to Sir Olivers, my self.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I can tell you another circumstance of his dishonesty too.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: He loves, and is belov'd, (I mean dishonestly) by my Lady Thrivewell; and this he told me himself boastingly, that I might yeild the sooner.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Dare you justifie this?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Yes indeed, dare I to their faces.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And so you shall.—Mr. Saveall, your servant. [Enter Save.

sp.speaker: Save.
sp.p: Mr. Bellamy, my Lord, is telling out the hundred pound at Sir Olivers, for you; but my Lord, there is a little difference in Sir Olivers Family, that my Lady desires your Lordship to compose, if possible.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
With all my heart. My Coach:—You must along, Mrs. Saleware.
Exit Lord, leading Mrs. Saleware, Tom. and Saveall, follow.

div.head: SCENE Changes
To sir Olivers House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver, Lady Thrivewell, Careless, Phebe, Closett, and Wat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: No, Villain, Ile have no more to do with thee. Ile leave thee to thy own shame and poverty.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: All that's thine, Ile turn out after thee; your Phebe, too, your virtuous Mistris, take her, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I thank you for nothing, this was a moveable that belong'd to me, before your virtuous Wife lay'd us together.— Who the Devil wou'd have imagin'd, she shou'd have Gilted me so? a young hansome proper fellow as I am to?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, have a care what you say of my Wife for I shall lay you fast enough else.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Is this—your witness, Sir; this pretious villain? [Points to Watt.

sp.speaker: Watt.
sp.p: No villain neither, Sir, since I have not betray'd my Master, for you turn'd me off basely.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Here's another of your Engins, this old Deceptio visus, that put me to Bed to the wrong Woman.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentleman,—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But if, Mr. Bellamy, had been the Man, I suppose, Madam, you wou'd have kept your word; and old Mother Damnable, wou'd have brought the right party.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: What means he?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie, George, you'll be asham'd of this anon?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
Faith, I shall not, and since you have betray'd me, I'll
ruine you; therefore hear me, Oh thou credulous Knight, what I've to say unto thee.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What canst thou say, good George, to my prejudice? Hold yet, whilst thy credit may be saved.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Not I, it shall out, unless you bribe me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not a farthing,—and see who'l have the worst on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: What would the Villian say to thy dishonour?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That, which if you are no contented Cuckold, will make you mad, Sir, it will:—you think I have done so lewd a thing in courting her,—but there's that smooth-fac'd young fellow, Bellamy, has courted her, and all the rest—I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Mr. Bellamy! it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But it can, Sir; there's her procurer, old dark Lanthorn can tell you more.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Who I? oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Oh, she was chamber'd up with him at least two hours, fair time,—under pretence of borrowing money; but you may guess his farther bus'ness, if you have any sense.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I'l not believe this, Sir; 'tis malice.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: 'Tis fit you shou'd see't done, indeed, and great pity you did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Saveall, if this be true, where's all my Reputation?—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And for that Rascal, Watt, there, I'l give you an account of him, which yet you never had: have you forgot, how we rescu'd you on Hounslow-heath, when you believ'd your self set on by Thieves?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: No, I have not forgot it; wou'd I had lost my Money nay a Limb, rather than have been by thee preserv'd.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That project, Sir, was his, to get me into your favour gain; the Robbers, as you thought 'em, were his acquaintance, Rogues of his managing, but to say truth, we meant no hurt, only I was forc'd, to colour the bus'ness, to give him a cut over the Pate, wou'd 't had kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Was't his Plot? I am glad to find him a fellow of that ingenuity: I love him for't.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Do you? then pray take notice, 'twas my own Plot, mine, Sir, to get my self into your favour.

sp.speaker: Watt.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, my Master's in the right, 'twas his Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir OIiv.
sp.p:
'Twas witty whose soe're 'twas, and I like it well,
wou'd all the rest of the Actions of your life were as well.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Well, Sir, now you know my mind, and I'l take my leave; farewel, Nuncle. Come away, Phebe, I have been an unkind Dog to thee, that's truth: but come, I'l e'en make thee amends, and marry thee, and having no better way to live, e'en fell Coffee with thee.—Come away.— [Offers to go.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray call him back; to let him go in this condition will undo him, and I desire to be clear'd too, before he goes of, the aspersion he has laid on me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, you shall stay, and answer it before Authority.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if you have a mind to have your house thought a Bawdy house, I can stay, and prove it.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Mrs. Crostil is come to wait on your Ladyship.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Crostil, and a little after Clare. drest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This is a great favour, Madam. Sir Oliver, pray entertain Mrs. Crostil a little.— [La. goes to Mrs. Clare aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Methinks you all look disorder'd, I hope, Sir Oliver, you and your Nephew have a good understanding.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: No, Madam, nor do I desire to have any with such a Villain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: How, Sir? nay, if you rail at him 'twill make me love him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Then you are wretched.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Nay, then I'm resolv'd to love him—Pray what's she he makes such love to?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: A common wench, that's with child by him; she pleads a Contract with him, and he'l marry her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Still you raise my flame to a greater height.—Mr. Careless, pray let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Who mean you, Madam,—me? I'm not at leisure now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: What the Duce was I made of, that his contempt of me increases my fire. Sir, I must needs speak with you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What have you to say? Widow, you are come too late, Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Pray walk a little this way.—I must speak to you alone. [They go aside.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray keep your self conceal'd, my Lord will be [To Clara. here presently, and shall do you reason; he has mortgag'd a great part of his Estate to Sir Oliver, and the Forfeiture's out, and he shall be just to you, or we'l undo him.—Sir Oliver, pray whatever reason you have to be displeas'd with your Nephew your self, do not ruin his fortune with the widow.— [Aside to Sir Oliv.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Tempt me not, widow, to your own ruin, if I shou'd be so unlucky as to marry you, you are certainly undone, for I am one you cannot live with above a fortnight, you are fine limb'd and delicate, and I shall spoil you.—Here's one that knows my strength, and will hold me tack.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Nor prithee never try,—I advise you in time, widow, this wench here is only fit for me.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Is my profer'd passion scorn'd?—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Faith no, widow, but I shall never merit you:—besides, I am ingag'd, widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: To that woman?—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Yes, to that woman; what exceptions have you to her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Why she's a wench, a common prostitute.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Hark ye, have a care what you say (I advise you) before witness, do not abuse a woman I design to make a wife of, lest I hamper your Estate, widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: She shall not be your wife, no woman but I shall marry you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Have a care what you say before witness again, widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: Call all to hear me, Sir Oliver, and the rest be witness I give my self to this Gentleman.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Here's one forbids the Banes, widow. [To Phebc.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: You shall compound with her.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But what said King Harry? Conscience,—conscience, widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, give me your hand, beer witness all, I plight my Faith to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Then you are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs Cr.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis too late to advise, I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Have I caught you, widow,—hah, ha.—Farewel, Nuncle.—And yet—Conscience pulls me back.—Besides, widow, the woman is not satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: I'l give her three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: The woman is not such a fool to take it.

sp.speaker: Watt.
sp.p: But the woman shall be so wise to take it, for what ever you all think, I do not love my Master so ill, to spoil his Fortune. And, Sir, truth is, I have receiv'd—some favors,—as they say, from Mrs. Phebe, as well as you, that is, she has been kind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I thought so.

sp.speaker: Watt.
sp.p: And I'm content to marry and make her honest, if she can get any addition to this Lady's bounty, to make her any fortune.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was well said, Watt, and I'l promise the other hundred, in lieu of that I had in Wares of her Kinswoman, with your permission, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Watt, go for the Parson then, we'l have 'em married presently. [Ex. Watt.

div.stage: Enter Lord, Tom Saleware, and Ali.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, in obedience to your commands, I am come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have honor'd me, my Lord, tho our difference is almost at an end, yet I have something to deliver to your Lordship in private.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, I have also a question to ask you in private too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I shall be glad of any occasion to serve your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, will you withdraw a little? only this Gentlewoman may be witness of what I have to ask you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I fancy what 'tis already, and must intreat your Lordship to speak it out, what e're it be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: 'T wou'd not be for your Honor, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am not of your opinion, my Lord, and that I may let you see I am not, I'l speak it for you: You come to ask me, and this woman to accuse me with dishonourable Love to a servant of yours, Bellamy I mean, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, it is.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This pleases me, indeed she has reveng'd her self handsomely; I have a Kinsman here of that opinion.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But, Madam, I recant, 'twas in the days of my debauch and brutality, I am reform'd now by your vertues only,—and humbly beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, is not Bellamy, here?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He will be presently, my Lord, but now your Lordship, has question'd me, I hope I may have the same freedom with you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, you may command me any thing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray where's my Sister Clara?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Is that a question for me to answer, Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, and which in Honour you are bound to answer: Did you not betray her to shame and infamy, and rob'd her of her Virgin purity?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I did not ravish her, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I do not say you did. But you had Flattery which did much more than force; I ask not her Honour back, but her life, and self, for we have never heard of her since that fatal Treachery of yours, and 'tis of you that I demand her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You, cannot sure comple me to return her, if I cou'd?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: But she shall, Sir, and I will be her Champion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Her loss, Madam, is a greater Grief to me, than 'tis to you;—but for you, Sir, I shall find a time to try your prowess.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But you shall not, Sir, Ile end the controversie.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I am amaz'd,—Clara,—and my Bellamy's the same.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, your Bellamy, is the wrong'd Clara.—Do you not blush to see me?—I'm come to claim your vows, so often sworn, and so long broken.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: So, I was like to have made fine work.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Bless me! Bellamy, a Woman?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word, I hope.

sp.speaker: Watt.
sp.p: Sir, the Parson's come.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Come, Widow, dare you sign, seal, and deliver?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir. [Ex. Careless, Widow, Watt, and Phebe.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Being by you undone, and made unfit to look abroad with Honour, and more unfit to live, but in the presence of you whom I ador'd; I did assume that Masculine habit, to let you see that I had rather live but by your sight alone, than be my self in any other part o'th' world; and by your sight alone, cou'd better contain my self, than she, the Mistris whom you so admir'd could, with the dear possession of you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You melt my soul.—Pray let me make new vows to you, or well confirm the old.— [Go aside.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Well, I am absolutely lost and undon in my Lords favor.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word. Come, come, I do suspect this is all but a plot to make me jealous.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Wou'd you not be laught at now, sweet Mrs. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, indeed, Madam; nor shall she be by the proudest she that wears a head; or if she be, it will not make me jealous: Sapientia mea mihi, is my Motto still.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yet I confess, this young Bellamy, and I have been bed-fellows some years since. Come be not out of countenance, I will not tell what my Husband did with you last term.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nor shall you make me jealous, Madam, what'ere they did. Efacks not I, sweet Ali.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Can you forgive what's past, and take a penitent man to your mercy?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My Lord, if you'll repair my Sisters honour, Sir Oliver, shall give you in your Mortgage?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: 'Tis all I wish on Earth to do so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Then, Sir, Ile restore your writings, and by it make her as good a Fortune as the Widow, and there's within a Parson shall end the difference.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It shall be done, Sir Oliver. —For you, Mrs. Saleware, go home, look to your Shop, and please your Husband; for from this day, Ile never see you more.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: I see all things are transitory,—and will turn Honest, and Thomas, you shall have no more fears of jealousie.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A Pox of jealousie, I wish that were the worst grievance in the Nation, the jealousie that troubles my Noddle. No, no; Sapientia, &c. is my Motto.

div.stage: Enter Careless, Crostill, Watt, and Phebe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: See, they are already Married.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What, my Cozin Phebe Gimcrack, too,—and 'efack, Ile take a frisk for joy. Watt get some Musick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cr.
sp.p: You shall not need, Sir, I have 'em at hand.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
Well, Uncle, I hope we shall now be Friends, and
according as I behave my self, let me have your favour,—you must all Dine with me to day; and at night, Widow—Ile say no more.—

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Well, Sir, as I shall see how you behave your self, I shall prove my self a loving Uncle.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I will be your Heir yet, in spight of ill Luck, and all my damn'd Debaucheries, which now farewell to.—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: See, the Musick's here indeed, we'll lead the Bride a Dance, and then they shall do as much for us, Clara.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now, Clare, that you and I may happy prove,
The Priest within shall consummate our Love.

div.head: EPILOGUE:
Spoken by TOM. SALEWARE.
div.l: TOM. face about, with harmeless Rallery,
Instruct the Salewares of the middle Gallery.
Dear Friends, go home and look unto your Wives,
Bid 'em keep in and mend their gadding lives;
They all have got a trick to see a Lord,
—Yet ne'er the sooner for a hasty word.
I mean no harm, for there are Wives that do
Keep open Shop, and trade as well as you;
Deal by retail, and are to Husbands aiding,
And oftentimes, have much the better Trading.
When time and place are fit, I'll name you some
Who keep a journy-man, or two at home.
I'll say no more; truth sometimes hatred draws:
—Yet

l.hi: I'll not be dasht, nor basht, in a good Cause.

div.l: I am a Glass in which you all may view,
What strange good Natur'd things are most of you.
Tho you'll believe no Man i th' way of Trade,
Yet what believing Fools, by Wives you're made?
Three years you're marry'd, and have ne'r a Son,
Your Wives make visits, and the job is don,
She smiles to see you Rock and Sing, by, by,
And think 'tis Yours; ah,—Stultitia tua tibi.
And of your Wives a Pattern see in Aly,
When Trading's dead, they all will strike a Tally;
Yet my dear Friends, be not at this dejected,
Carry't as I do, fair, and stand Corrected:
Act not a Henrick, or a jealous Diego,
'Tis safer much, to be an Assenego.
Then let my Wife go visit Knight, or Lord;
Or they come to her, I do not care one—hum,—

l.hi: Sapientia mea mihi, is my word.
